Award.AbstractNarration:
This project continues the study of the application and theory of Rota-Baxter algebra and related structures that have arisen from the interaction between mathematics and physics. The application part of this project pursues the mathematical understanding of the renormalization of perturbative quanturm field theory and the application of the renormalization method in the study of mathematical objects, such as divergent multiple zeta values and Riemann integrals. Multivariable special values of convex cones and their renormalization will also be studied in connection with the Todd class of the related toric varieties. A relative generalization of the Rota-Baxter operator called the O-operator will be studied in the context of Yang-Baxter equations and integrable systems. The theoretical part of the project considers the classification, representation and chain conditions of these structures, and the relationship among Rota-Baxter related operators, shuffle type products and special operads such as the dendriform, pre-Lie and PostLie operads.

The Rota-Baxter operator is an algebraic generalization of the integration operator in analysis. The study of this operator was independently carried out by mathematicians, with motivation from probability theory, and by physicists, as solutions of the classical Yang-Baxter equation. Further important applications were subsequently found in several areas of physics and mathematics, including quantum field theory, Yang-Baxter equations, number theory, operads and Hopf algebras. The highly recursive, tree-like definition of the Rota-Baxter operator has also generated interest in its connection with computational mathematics and combinatorics. Further study of this operator will contribute to the understanding of the role it plays in such diverse areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Rota-Baxter operator is an algebraic generalization of the integration operator in analysis. Its study was independently carried out by mathematicians, with motivation from probability, and by physicists, as solutions of the classical Yang-Baxter equation. Further important applications were subsequently found in several areas of physics and mathematics, including quantum field theory, integrable systems, number theory, operads and Hopf algebras. The highly recursive, tree-like definition of the Rota-Baxter operator has also generated interest in its connection with computational mathematics and combinatorics. Thus its study is crucial for these wide range of applications and connections.

This project continued the study of the theory and application of Rota-Baxter algebra and related structures with emphasis on the interaction between mathematics and physics.

The theoretical part of the project investigated the classification and localization of Rota-Baxter algebras. The PI and coauthors also constructed free integro-differential algebras with motivation from boundary value problems. More generally, they studied Rota-Baxter related operators to address a problem raised by Rota on classification of linear operators on algebras. They also established a general framework of splitting and replicating of operads to understand a large class of algebraic structures introduced in the past two decades.

The application part of this project pursued the application of the renormalization method from quantum field theory in the study of mathematic objects, such as divergent multiple zeta values and integrals. Multivariable special values from convex cones and their renormalization were also studied in connection with the general Euler-Maclaurin formula. A relative generalization of the Rota-Baxter operator called the O-operator was studied in the context of Yang-Baxter equations and integrable systems. Applications were also given to the generalizations of Euler’s sum formula and decomposition formula in the context of multiple zeta values.

The outcomes of this project were presented in over twenty journal articles as well as one book authored by the PI and coauthors.
